title: Kenya: CBK Steps Into Safaricom, Equity Duel
text:
Kenya: Ignore Kaimenyi Move to Shut Private Schools, Says Association By Lilian Ochieng 
The Central Bank of Kenya has waded into the tag of war between banks and mobile money transfer platforms with a proposal to harmonise transaction charges. 
Through the 2011 National Payment System Act, the regulator is setting up a payment services management board (the Payments Association of Kenya) that will draw in telcos, switches, aggregators, electronic-money issuers, banks and other financial services providers in Kenya. 
According to the head of future financial systems at Financial Services Deepening (FSD) Victor Malu, the platform will bring "Equity Bank and M-Pesa to the same table to talk about payments, inter-operability, eventually lowering the cost of transactions". 
Also: Equity protests rise in M-Pesa charges 
Mr Malu spoke on the sidelines of the Africa Information and Communications Technology Exhibition and Conference (AITEC) Banking & Mobile Money in Nairobi on Tuesday. 
NO RULES 
"The regulations became law in August last year, brought into play because mobile money had no rules governing them yet there was (a) need to create order in the sector," said CBK's head of the national payment system, Mr Stephen Mwaura Nduati. 
The Payment Association of Kenya will allow for harmonisation of interchange charges across varied financial service providers. The operators will share infrastructure and rules of engagement with each other and settlement of payments. 
Read: Equity takes on Safaricom with money transfer 
FSD is putting into operation the regulations and borrowing from the experience of South Africa, the UK and Australia, which already have such institutions operating. 
"Central Bank will empower members of the association to self-regulate each other. The body is under formation and when institutionalised, it will create regulations that will manage interchange charges," said Kenya Bankers Association CEO Habil Olaka. 
The changes come into play after a surcharge fight that has seen Equitel money transfer charges rise following Safaricom's decision to increase bank-to-mobile charges. 
The changes, which are currently being reviewed, have prompted Equity Bank to demand an explanation from Safaricom. Equity Bank CEO James Mwangi said the charges that affected Equity transactions made from Equitel to M-Pesa took effect on August 1. Kenya
